title: Marc Benioff
content:
{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2019}} {{use American English|date=May 2021}} {{short description|American businessman}} {{Infobox person | name = Marc Benioff | image = Marc Benioff.jpg | caption = Benioff in 2021 | birth_name = Marc Russell Benioff | birth_place = [[San Francisco]], [[California]], U.S. | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1964|9|25}} | spouse = Lynne Krilich | children = 2 | known_for = Founder, chairman and co-CEO, [[Salesforce]]
Co-chair and owner, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''{{cite web|url=https://time.com/6102640/jane-goodall-environment-hope/|title=The Enduring Hope of Jane Goodall |website=time.com|access-date=March 30, 2022}} | education = [[University of Southern California]] (BS) }} '''Marc Russell Benioff''' (born September 25, 1964)http://www.worldcat.org/identities/lccn-n2009036451 is an American [[internet entrepreneur]] and philanthropist. He is the co-founder, chairman and CEO of [[Salesforce]], an enterprise [[cloud computing]] company.{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/marc-benioff/|title=Marc Benioff|website=Forbes|language=en|access-date=December 30, 2018}} In September 2018, Benioff acquired ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''. == Early life and education == Benioff was raised in a [[Jewish]] family[http://www.jpost.com/JewishWorld/JewishNews/Article.aspx?id=207507 Jerusalem Post: "Jews take 5 of top 6 spots in annual list of top US givers" By JACOB BERKMAN] September 2, 2011[http://ejewishphilanthropy.com/jewish-philanthropy-2-0/ Jewish Philanthropy: "Jewish Philanthropy 2.0"] February 23, 2011 in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]]. He graduated from [[Burlingame High School (California)|Burlingame High School]] in 1982.[http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Marc-Benioff-CEO-makes-philanthropy-a-priority-2353592.php San Francisco Gate: "Marc Benioff, CEO, makes philanthropy a priority" by Casey Newton] July 24, 2011 Benioff received a Bachelor of Science in [[business administration]] from the [[University of Southern California]], where he was a member of the [[Tau Kappa Epsilon]] [[Fraternities and sororities|fraternity]], in 1986.{{Cite web |last=Lynley |first=Matt |title=Frat Boys Are Taking Over The Tech World |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/frat-boys-are-taking-over-the-tech-world-2012-2 |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=Business Insider |language=en-US}} Benioff is a second cousin of [[showrunner]] and television writer [[David Benioff]], known for ''[[Game of Thrones]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/how-these-famous-benioffs-are-related-2015-4|title=How these famous Benioffs are related |first=Julie |last=Bort |date=April 12, 2015 |work=[[Business Insider]] |access-date=March 28, 2016}} He is married to Lynne Benioff and has two children. The family lives in San Francisco, California. == Career == While in high school, Benioff sold his first application, How to Juggle, for $75. In 1979, when he was 15, Benioff founded Liberty Software, creating and selling games such as ''Flapper'' and ''King Arthur's Heir'' for the [[Atari 8-bit]].{{Cite magazine |last=Duberman |first=David |date=January 1984 |title=ROM Fun: Survey of recent cartridge games |url=https://archive.org/details/1984-01-anticmagazine |magazine=Antic |pages=[https://archive.org/details/1984-01-anticmagazine/page/n61 62]–63}}{{Cite web |last=Bort |first=Julie |title=The Fabulous Life Of Tech Billionaire Marc Benioff |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/the-fab-life-of-billionaire-marc-benioff-2014-2 |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=Business Insider |language=en-US}} Royalties from these games helped Benioff pay for college.{{cite book |author1=Benioff, Marc |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XX5QJ7hfDW8C&pg=PR18 |title=Behind the Cloud: The Untold Story of How Salesforce.com Went from Idea to Billion-Dollar Company-and Revolutionized an Industry |author2=Adler, Carlyle |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |year=2009 |isbn=978-0-470-53592-9 |pages=xviii–xx |author-link=Marc Benioff}} While at [[University of Southern California|USC]], Benioff had an internship as a programmer at [[Apple Inc.|Apple]].{{Cite web |last=Sauer |first=Megan |date=2022-02-22 |title=A teenage Marc Benioff cold-called an Apple executive — and got his dream internship |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/02/22/salesforces-marc-benioff-what-i-learned-as-a-teenaged-apple-intern.html |access-date=2022-02-26 |website=CNBC |language=en}} He joined [[Oracle Corporation]] in a customer-service role after graduating. Benioff worked at Oracle for 13 years in a variety of sales, marketing, and product development roles. At 23, he was named Oracle's Rookie of the Year. Three years later, he became the youngest person in the company's history to earn the title of vice president. Benioff founded [[Salesforce]] in 1999{{Cite web |title=The stratospheric rise of Marc Benioff and Salesforce |url=https://fortune.com/longform/marc-benioff-salesforce-slack-acquisition-diversity-inclusion-fortune-500/ |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=Fortune |language=en}} in a San Francisco apartment and defined its mission in a marketing statement as "The End of Software."[https://www.salesforce.com/blog/2013/03/how-to-turn-a-simple-idea-into-a-high-growth-company.html Salesforce Blog: "Marc Benioff: How to Turn a Simple Idea into a High-Growth Company" By Marc Benioff] March 8, 2013 This was a slogan he used frequently to preach about software on the Web, and used as a guerilla marketing tactic against the dominant CD-ROM CRM competitor [[Siebel Systems|Siebel]] at the time.{{Cite web|date=2020-12-06|title=The Marketing Genius of Marc Benioff|url=https://viralwegrow.com/blog/evolving-fashion-marc-benioffs-marketing-genius/|access-date=2020-12-07|website=ViralWeGrow|language=en}} Salesforce was the first company to offer [[software as a service]], which allowed people and companies to rent software over the internet instead of installing the programs on machines.{{Cite web |last=Field |first=Hayden |title=Marc Benioff Reached Millionaire Status by Age 25 -- and 9 Other Things to Know About the Co-Founder of Salesforce |url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/320186 |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=Entrepreneur |date=September 17, 2018 |language=en}} Benioff extended Salesforce's offerings in the early 2000s with the idea of a platform that allowed developers to create applications.{{Cite web |title=The story of why Marc Benioff gifted the AppStore.com domain to Steve Jobs |url=https://social.techcrunch.com/2020/01/02/the-story-of-why-marc-benioff-gifted-the-appstore-com-domain-to-steve-jobs/ |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=TechCrunch |language=en-US}} Benioff also serves on the World Economic Forum's Board of Trustees and USC Board of Trustees.{{Cite web |last=Rogers |first=Matt Weinberger, Taylor Nicole |title=The rise of Marc Benioff, the bombastic owner of Time Magazine who just became Salesforce's sole CEO, has an $8 billion fortune, and owns a 5-acre compound in Hawaii |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/the-rise-of-salesforce-ceo-marc-benioff-2016-3 |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=Business Insider |language=en-US}} On September 16, 2018, Marc and his wife Lynne bought ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' for $190 million.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/16/business/dealbook/time-magazine-salesforce-marc-benioff.html?action=click&module=RelatedLinks&pgtype=Article|title=Time Magazine Is Bought by Marc Benioff, Salesforce Billionaire|newspaper=The New York Times |date=September 16, 2018|language=en-GB|last1=Chozick |first1=Amy |last2=Gelles |first2=David }} === Co-written work === Benioff has co-written four books about business and technology. In 2004, he co-wrote ''Compassionate Capitalism: How Corporations Can Make Doing Good an Integral Part of Doing Well'' with Karen Southwick.{{Cite web |date=2021-10-20 |title=The goodness business: how woke capitalism turned virtue into profit |url=https://www.newstatesman.com/long-reads/2021/10/the-goodness-business-how-woke-capitalism-turned-virtue-into-profit |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=New Statesman |language=en-US}} In 2006, he co-wrote ''The Business of Changing the World: 20 Great Leaders on Strategic Corporate Philanthropy'' with Carlye Adler. In 2009, he co-wrote ''Behind the Cloud: The Untold Story of How Salesforce.com Went from Idea to Billion-Dollar Company and Revolutionized an Industry'', also with Carlye Adler.{{Cite web |last=Kim |first=Eugene |title=Billionaire CEO Marc Benioff is writing a sequel to his best-selling memoir about Salesforce — and wants your help |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/salesforce-ceo-marc-benioff-is-writing-a-new-book-2016-1 |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=Business Insider |language=en-US}} In 2019, he again co-wrote ''Trailblazer: The Power of Business as the Greatest Platform for Change'', with [[Monica Langley]]. == Influence and honors == [[File:Marc R. Benioff World Economic Forum 2013.jpg|thumb|Benioff during the [[World Economic Forum|WEF]] 2013]]In 2003, [[George W. Bush|President Bush]] appointed Benioff co-chair of the President's Information Technology Advisory Committee.{{Cite web |last=Feloni |first=Richard |title=Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff explains why a Hindu guru and Colin Powell were critical mentors |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/marc-benioff-colin-powell-advice-salesforce-2016-3 |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=Business Insider |language=en-US}} In 2009, Benioff was named a Young Global Leader by the [[World Economic Forum]], and is a member of its Board of Trustees.{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2009/02/25/world-economic-forum-announces-new-batch-of-young-global-leaders-mark-zuckerberg-chad-hurley-kevin-rose-and-more/|title=World Economic Forum Announces New Batch Of Young Global Leaders (Mark Zuckerberg, Chad Hurley, Kevin Rose And More)|publisher=[[TechCrunch]]|language=en-US|date=February 25, 2009}}{{Cite news |date=2022-01-13 |title=C.E.O.s Were Our Heroes, at Least According to Them |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/13/business/davos-man-marc-benioff-book.html |access-date=2022-03-30 |issn=0362-4331}} In 2012, he was named one of the "Best CEOs in the World" by ''[[Barron's (newspaper)|Barron]]''{{'}}s[http://www.barrons.com/articles/SB50001424053111904797004577283662192414888 Barron's: "World's Best CEOs" By Andrew Bary] March 26, 2012 and received ''[[The Economist]]''{{'}}s Innovation Award.[https://www.economist.com/news/technology-quarterly/21567206-innovation-awards-our-annual-prizes-recognise-successful-innovators-eight The Economist: "And the winners were..." By The Economist Staff] December 1, 2012 In 2014, ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' readers voted him "Businessperson of the Year."[http://fortune.com/2014/11/12/businessperson-year-readers-choice/ Fortune: "Vote: Businessperson of the Year - Championship Round" By Fortune Editors] November 12, 2014 In 2016, Fortune magazine named him one of the "World's 50 Greatest Leaders."[http://fortune.com/2016/03/24/worlds-greatest-leaders-2016-intro/ Fortune: "The World's 50 Greatest Leaders" By Geoff Colvin] March 25, 2016 == Philanthropy == [[File:Marc Benioff in 2009.jpg|thumb|Marc Benioff in 2009]]Benioff founded the Salesforce Foundation in 2000.{{cite web |date=July 26, 2014 |title=Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff: The big giver |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/salesforce-ceo-marc-benioff-the-big-giver/ |publisher=[[CNET]]}} Marc and Lynne Benioff have been included in lists of top givers by [[Forbes]] and the [[The Chronicle of Philanthropy|Chronicle of Philanthropy]].{{cite web |title=America's Top Givers of 2016 |url=https://www.forbes.com/top-givers/ |access-date=September 19, 2018 |website=Forbes}}{{cite web |date=February 6, 2011 |title=No. 10 (tied): Marc R. and Lynne Benioff |url=https://philanthropy.com/article/No-10-tied-Marc-R-and/159141 |access-date=September 19, 2018 |website=philanthropy.com}}[https://philanthropy.com/article/Young-Tech-Donors-Take-Leading/151779 The Chronicle of Philanthropy: "Young Tech Donors Take Leading Role in Philanthropy 50" By Alex Daniels and Maria Di Mento] February 8, 2015[https://philanthropy.com/article/Conservative-Billionaire/235234 The Chronicle of Philanthropy: "Bequests Put Conservative Billionaire Richard Scaife Atop List of America's 50 Biggest Donors" By Maria Di Mento and Drew Lindsay] February 9, 2016 In 2010, the Benioffs donated $100 million to [[UCSF Benioff Children's Hospital|UCSF Children's Hospital]].{{Cite web |last=Savchuk |first=Katia |title=San Francisco's Giant of Generosity |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/katiasavchuk/2014/06/19/san-franciscos-giant-of-generosity/ |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=Forbes |language=en}} In 2014, they donated an additional $100 million to the hospital and $50 million to fund research on premature birth. In October 2020, Marc and Lynne Benioff were founding partners of [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Prince William]]'s [[Earthshot prize|Earthshot Prize]], a program for finding solutions to environmental issues.{{Cite web |title='Next 10 years are critical': Prince William backs £50m climate change project Earthshots |url=https://www.thenational.ae/world/europe/next-10-years-are-critical-prince-william-backs-50m-climate-change-project-earthshots-1.1090175 |access-date=2020-10-13 |website=The National |date=October 8, 2020 |language=en}} In October 2021, Benioff pledged a $200 million donation to plant trees and fund ecologically-focused entrepreneurs.{{Cite web |last=Dolan |first=Kerry A. |title=Salesforce Billionaire Marc Benioff Pledges $200 Million For Reforestation, Climate Entrepreneurs |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kerryadolan/2021/10/28/salesforce-billionaire-marc-benioff-pledges-200-million-for-reforestation-climate-entrepreneurs/ |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=Forbes |language=en}} Salesforce also donated $100 million to the same causes.{{Cite web |title=Marc and Lynne Benioff, Salesforce donate $300M to encourage climate action |url=https://social.techcrunch.com/2021/10/28/marc-and-lynne-benioff-salesforce-donate-300m-to-encourage-climate-action/ |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=TechCrunch |date=October 28, 2021 |language=en-US}} In 2019, the Benioffs donated $30 million to the Center for Vulnerable Populations for the [[Benioff Homelessness and Housing Initiative]] to study the impacts of homelessness, housing, and health.{{Cite web |title=UCSF Launches New Benioff Homelessness and Housing Initiative with $30M Gift |url=https://www.ucsf.edu/news/2019/05/414316/ucsf-launches-new-benioff-homelessness-and-housing-initiative-30m-gift |website=UCSF Launches New Benioff Homelessness and Housing Initiative with $30M Gift | UC San Francisco}} == Social activism == In March 2015, Benioff announced Salesforce would cancel all employee programs and travel in the state of Indiana after the passing of the [[Religious Freedom Restoration Act (Indiana)|Religious Freedom Restoration Act]], a bill that would allow companies and individuals to choose not to serve LGBT individuals based on religious beliefs.[http://www.ibj.com/articles/52427-salesforce-ceo-were-cancelling-travel-to-indiana indiana Business Journal: "Salesforce CEO: We're canceling travel to Indiana" By Jared Council] March 26, 2015 Benioff led an effort of business leaders fighting back against the legislation, leading to a revised version of the bill being signed into law that prohibited businesses from denying services to someone based on sexual orientation or gender identity.[https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/04/07/marc-benioff-indiana_n_7017032.html The Huffington Post: "The CEO Who Took On Indiana's Anti-LGBT Law — And Won" By Alexander C. Kaufman] April 7, 2015 In April 2015, Benioff announced that he would review salaries at Salesforce to ensure men and women were paid equally.[https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/04/23/salesforce-pay-gap_n_7126892.html The Huffington Post: "Salesforce CEO Takes Radical Step To Pay Men And Women Equally" By Emily Peck] April 23, 2015 In February 2016, Benioff announced that Salesforce would reduce investments in Georgia and cancel a conference if HB 757, a bill that would allow businesses to decline services to same-sex couples, was passed.[http://fortune.com/2016/02/26/salesforce-marc-benioff-georgia-gay-marriage/ Fortune: "Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff Battles Georgia Over Gay Rights" By Jonathan Vanian] February 26, 2016 The governor vetoed the bill.[http://politics.blog.ajc.com/2016/03/28/breaking-nathan-deal-will-veto-georgias-religious-liberty-bill/ Atlanta Journal-Constitution: "BREAKING: Nathan Deal vetoes Georgia's 'religious liberty' bill" By Greg Bluestein] April 9, 2016 In an October 2018 interview with ''[[The Guardian]]'', Benioff criticized other technology industry executives for "hoarding" their money and refusing to help [[Homelessness|the homeless]] in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]].{{Cite web |last=Levin |first=Sam |date=October 17, 2018 |title=Salesforce CEO: tech billionaires 'hoard their money' and won't help homeless |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/oct/17/salesforce-ceo-marc-benioff-san-francisco-homeless-interview |via=www.theguardian.com}} In November, Benioff announced his support for San Francisco's Prop C measure that would increase taxes on large corporations to aid unhoused residents in the city.{{Cite web |last=Ghaffary |first=Shirin |date=2018-11-14 |title=Marc Benioff says he had rabbis and imams supporting the Prop C homelessness tax — but not tech CEOs |url=https://www.vox.com/2018/11/14/18093170/marc-benioff-homeless-tax-prop-c-tech-ceos |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=Vox |language=en}} In September 2021, Benioff announced that Salesforce would relocate any Texas employees who wanted to move after an [[Texas Heartbeat Act|abortion law]] went into effect.{{Cite web |date=2021-09-11 |title=Salesforce to help workers leave states over abortion laws |url=https://apnews.com/article/technology-business-texas-greg-abbott-marc-benioff-98094859a011193d3c83d6a4ff1e7a8a |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=AP NEWS |language=en}}{{Cite web |last=Novet |first=Jordan |date=2021-09-11 |title=Salesforce offers to relocate employees and their families after Texas abortion law goes into effect |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/09/10/salesforce-offers-to-relocate-employees-from-texas-after-abortion-bill.html |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=CNBC |language=en}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==
